uOKcof-C4N4GysAsOjoh_Q.text: The Mexican equivilent to wagamama. Same formula different food. Went for business lunch. Far too noisey and tables not condusive to conversation. Not sure about value for money but my food (taco salad with black beans - veggie) was good but unremarkable. Gaucomole was disappointingly bland and not blended. Would not rush back.

uXfZIeU9ftXmjVR2kiOTiw.text: The mexican food here was fresh and delicious and my three colleagues and I were loving the tapas section of the menu so that we could try a number of dishes instead of one huge main. (Especially good were the taquitos) However, the service was quite spotty - we were given the wrong starter (although the waiter kindly let us keep both once we flagged him down and it was corrected!) and service in general was very slow. Considering the location and that most customers would be there for a work lunch - this should be faster!

LGL1vTMcBS9IDftNFFUE0g.text: Lovely food. Nice margarita. Good friendly and professional service. Pleasantly buzzy ambiance. Will definitely go back and looks a likely place for work colleagues.

J1LqDecX7-Ur1u94mFnk5w.text: I came with such high expectations - finally good Mexican food close to work! Left disapointed, it's alright and that means within Canary Wharf it's one of the better options but not the outstanding mexican food we had been promised.

8_Mg9EwKcRP9XBEYex0CGg.text: Fantastic burritos and a wonderful idea, can't fault it.

1-fEg2D0FcDi08vrHBmIWw.text: I was quite impressed by the array of offerings on the menu as well as the taste of everything that I ordered. I'd definitely go back! Its not the typical Mexican food you'd find in American- Mexican restaurants so the variety is very welcome. London doesn't have much in the way of Mexican options, so Wahaca is a great bet!

4RNyiApf7YaJ1zaR3xn52g.text: Having been to the Covent Garden restaurant a few times with good experiences, I hate to say that I'm disappointed with the Canary Wharf restaurant.  This was not so much because the food was any different but because the service was inefficient and rude.My friend and I went on a Wednesday evening about 9pm and it wasn't busy -  probably about 70% full.  While we were seated promptly, it took 15 minutes to get someone over to take our drink orders, which only happened because I had to finally get up and walk over to the group of waiters/waitresses standing around talking and ask if we could get someone to help us.  Turns out that our assigned waiter was not one of them and since we were not in their sections.   Strike one.  When we finally got our drinks, mine wasn't correct.  I clearly stressed "no salt" when I ordered my margarita but it came with salt.  It happens and I wasn't too fussed but when I sent it back and the girl looked annoyed and sighed.  Strike 2.  Finally our waiter came and was very polite and took our food orders.  When the food arrived it was all I have come to expect from Wahaca - fresh and tasty.  Being a native Texan, I know how Mexican food should taste and Wahaca almost gives me my fix - not quite but almost.  Then, as we were eating, I could not help but notice that the group of waiters/waitresses were arguing about something, right by our table- arms waving and everything.  Big no-no of customer service!  Sure, it's going to happen but should NEVER happen in front of customers.  Strike 3.I'd love to give this restaurant lots of praise but I cannot. They need to sort out their staff issues.  What could have been a perfect meal was ruined by whatever was going on with the staff that night.

SFOa3uZ4yteDTJYs9B8haw.text: The Wahaca empire is growing...a very welcome addition to the wharf. This particular site seems quite vast, perhaps because the space is quite open - all the more space, hurrah! As they don't take bookings, this probably isn't a bad thing at all. Order the huitlacoche quesadillas, the pork pibil and the fuerza salad. Try to convince your fellow diners that the black bean and chicken soup is 'yes, nice, good..' rather than revealing that it's amazing so you don't have to share it with them. I've become a tequila convert now and it's all Wahaca's fault - what they have on offer is a far cry from the student experiences that most of us associate with that particular beverage. Try the aged ones at the end of your meal. Leave room for churros. We didn't, and now we have to go back. Ack, what a chore...

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

Ihh5I52s4n_j_4DT-X4fFA.text: Ever since I left the States, I've missed Mexican food. It's a sad affliction - on my return trip to CHicago this year I was like a crazed desperate woman headed for Chipotle. Anyway, one of my boyfriend's favourtie foods ever which we had in California was fish tacos, and I haven;t found them here. Wahaca probably comes closest. The food is good - tasty, good size portions to try lots of items (I'd recommend the tasting plate for two, it's plentiful and good). The soft tacos are the only ones I've had in London which taste like, erm, soft tacos - it's the corn, I think. Anyway, yum. The atmosphere in the restaurant is also good, we were in a large group and were well looked after. However, afterwards, we headed up to the bar which was FREEZING - due to being made not-quite-airtight with a piece or transparent tarp - and EMPTY. The girl behind the bar served us with complete indifference, which seemed a bit odd since we were the only people there and you'd think she'd at least like having something to do to keep her warm. (Honestly, I had to sit under the heat lamp I was so cold). So - good food, I'll definitely go back, but I wouldn't bother with the bar.

ERkdStGY8P8Uq4o3VWRduQ.text: I like you London, but I didn't expect you to have Mexican food this good.  I mean, to be fair, if you go to Wahaca you need to manage your expectations. You are in a spice averse country far far away from Mexico... this is risky territory.  Yet, I can confidently say this is better than the Mexican food I ate in Beijing, and its also better than plenty of places in NYC.  Alright, fine, I guess thats like saying it is better than eating dirt.  I'll leave it at this:  If you are in London and  from somewhere with remotely decent Mexican food, it is inevitable that a time will come when you have an uncontrollable craving.  When that day comes, Wahaca will satisfy your needs and you will not leave pissed off at the food.  You might hate the service, but quit being such a negative nancy.

m-56eR0c2plWJUG5B3kerA.text: Pics @ Chopstix2Steakniveschopstix2steaknives.blog… Chains and branches, you sometimes get a bit wary and weary of them. However, not all are bad and some are worth the trip. I've been to Wahaca a few times now and I do enjoy the food here.When I don't really have a preference on what to order, I will usually go for the Market selection which comprises of a number of different items on the menu.3 pork pibil tacos1 large broad bean quesadilla3 chicken tinga tacos2 black bean tostadas2 new potato taquitoswith green rice and black beansYou probably can't go too wrong with the above selections. Everything is cooked well, flavoursome and will satisfy the tummy. My favourite are the taquitos, anything deep fried usually are. Sometimes when you want to eat somewhere that doesn't burn a hole in the wallet and still taste of something, Wahaca is one of this options that I will consider.Oh, and my favourite drink is the horchata which is almond and rice milk. A nice chill drink without being overly sweet.

BhUqV54i2RfHLlUN_pb4zA.text: Excellent food. Authentic Mexican cuisine. Nice to see that in London as your usual fare is tex mex rubbish. Pork pibil tacos are as good as any I have had in Mexico City taquerias. Very impressed by the authenticity and quality of food. Good Mexican beer selection too.Negative: service at the canary wharf branch is pretty terrible. Place was almost empty and the waiters still kept forgetting about us. Staff are pretty arrogant and lazy - they need better training.

WcKmpFG7cFKiWiTWfWYZ1w.text: As a native Southern Californian, I am always winging about the poor excuse for Mexican food in England. I think Wahaca is about as close as I'm gonna get on this side of the pond. I will forgive that the waitress said that they didn't sever jamaica, but that they did have a "refreshing hibiscus drink" because the food was good, fresh, and a great price. It's been the only place that has had decent corn tortillas, a pretty tasty mole, and a good margarita. The to-go veggie burrito with chips and guac almost made me feel at home. Sitting down in the restaurant, our waiter was great- timely, friendly, and helpful.

G-Rto7eUjdgVN9q8MjXuqg.text: Preface: This review has been written by a clueless European who has only ever been to Cancun on a drinking holiday and has never experienced the mythical nirvana that is 'good Mexican food'. Brand new to Canary Wharf is Wahaca, yay, wooh, Mexican food.... Ehhhh wah wah Wahaca, you are such a disappointment. Firstly I hate that you put red onion in your guac, this is no place for overpowering onion evilness. 2. Your waiters are far too concerned about what 'section' tables are in, if you aren't in their section, you are dead to them. This is not how you run a restaurant. C. Your fish tacos are crap. Three measly bits of fish gougon on a cold tortilla with far too much lettuce and a teaspoon of sauce is not what I was hoping for. I will conceded the portion of rice and beans was tasty. Conclusion: Waited ages to order and your food is admittedly fresh tasting, but eating a plate of lettuce will always feel airy, won't it? I'm sure one day I will find something at Wahaca that I like, so will probably try again in a couple of months. If anything, they have churros!

uiBJvKtj5GZiPkxKnUJUPA.text: We've been eating here for almost a year at least once a month. So to do a review is better late than never, plus we can say exactly how good the service was. The waiters are great - on the ball and fast. In all our visits (possible 20+) we had one bad situation with a hair in our food. Through no fault of their kitchen (the deserts are apparently from a factory and delivered daily), they apologised profusely and offered a kind discount for this. I'd have no problem eating here again despite that as the pulled pork burrito is wonderful. If they could always be stupidly juicy each time - that would be the icing on the cake. Maybe I should ask if that's possible next time!

thm1MpxoH3s7xsYwhm_oVg.text: I'm rounding up the star-age here, because, well, yay, I'm a fan, especially of the fish tacos, which are far from perfection, but get at least an A- for effort. I'm not going to lie here, I'm pretty awesome at eating Mexican food. I've lived in the Bay Area (props to El Charro) San Francisco (Mission = Mexican food heaven) and San Diego, which, in my opinion, arguably has better fish tacos than, well, Mexico. (Although it wouldn't stop us from taking a day-trip to Ensenada or Porto Nuevo, a small fishing village south of Tijuana that had an amazing lobster tail taco special. Ok, maybe that was the best.)Anyway, back to reality.  Back to London, where a poor avocado tree would die of depression before it died of frost in the dark, dark cold winter afternoons. Back to Wahaca. So, with all that in mind, the first time I had the fish tacos I thought they were pretty a-ok, a little too heavy on the battering and they were kind of smallish and looked like fish sticks. But they tasted good, and had plenty of chipotle-mayo sauce stuff on top. The side slaw was great outside and inside the taco, and the side of black beans, cilantro rice and sour-ed (why not just "sour," people?) cream was a tasty combo. Hence, I ate the entire plate. And I was stuffed.On my second visit, I wanted to try something else, but fell into the tractor beam of the fish taco plate again, and this time, the fish sticks, still over battered, were slightly bigger, and the tacos were messy but delicious in addition to the sides. Again, plate was clean. And for less than 8 GBP for a filling and tasty meal in a classy but comfortable atmosphere...I say yay.For a short recap: this place serves good Mex as far as London goes, has a creative street-food menu approach great for sharing if you don't  like fish tacos. Salsa is smokey and spicy, and if you ask them for more chips they'll give 'em to ya. Fun atmosphere and reasonable, even for broke students. Oh, and get the rice-milk Horacha drink if you can't splurge on the margaritas, like me!

o4X49vHqC9Zti4IqXnvCpg.text: Great as ever with wahaca, nice lively clean place with good good at a reasonable price.Good location, head to the bar for some great views. Order 2 or 3 smaller dishes and a side if your feeling hungry :) staff are helpful if your not sure what you want.

lpR14RADhjRD-gIEHOu5Qg.text: VERY authentic and great value. The menu was explained quite clearly and we ordered 4 small plates including quesedillas, toquitos, refried beans and guacamole which came with tortilla chips. The guacamole was the best and perfectly seasoned. Good value too.

6oGM2wvAVb2m5avzWCvV3Q.text: Once again on the hunt for good mexican food a friend tok me to Wahaca. It was not what I expected but the food was actually pretty good and the menu was different not just the taco & burrito thing. It is also good to come to with friends and you can share many dishes tapas-style. The atmosphere inside the restaurant is nice as it aims to create and street-food kinda atmosphere, but Wahaca is more on the expensive side.

evUrW2xAC2cgNOYTIBxMyQ.text: I am a repeat customer to Wahaca. Their food is always top notch, friendly, efficient service is great though when it gets crowded it can take a while to get the waiters attention. Consistency is sometimes an issue in that the waiters forget to inform you of any specials (usually comes on a post-it note that they need to slap on the menu). Prices are above average.

kVZkOJVXybwbnAiUtj86zw.text: I put my Sombrero on and visited this Mexican joint right on my doorstep.  In fact, I've been there a few times now.  The food is good and some of it is really spicy.  The service is not great, but this is London, so the service can be hit and miss.  If you like Mexican food, this place is for you.

rOKnJ2XLVgCSaK5wvc7Niw.text: Yes, Wahaca the third! They've done a cracking job on the decor and atmosphere for the Canary Wharf site. It's suspended above the square below (atop a Canteen, no less) which makes it feel nice and big, especially compared to the subterranean vibe of Covent Garden. It's also very colourful and friendly compared to the superclean, sharp and pointy aesthetic of the Wharf. The food is nigh on identical between all the Wahaca sites, and their quality control is perfect. All the staff did a brilliant job too; friendly and present when you need them. The trick to a good Wahaca experience, as I've said before, is to be adventurous with your order. My favourites are the black bean soup, pork scratchings with guacamole and fish tacos. The tequila is also excellent and a far cry from the pungent student nightmare that puts most of us off it for life. Give it a go. Order big. Share everything. Good times.

wzhZzS4XAUWDQ8MbqZ1gYw.text: Wahaca, Mexican Street Food...unique concept when it was first seen in Covent Garden and I am glad that it has now opened in Canary Wharf, where the young professionals can enjoy the pleasures of Mexican Cuisine that is not just typical and boring enchiladas and fajitas. The restaurant itself is really nice, on the second floor overlooking the park in Canary Wharf with the Skyscrapers in the background. The interior also is lovely with its open, comfortable, wooden and stylishly lit indoor. The food is also great; I recommend getting a few small dishes and eating it like Tapas...that way you will get a bit of everything and feel satisfied with the various and different flavours and experiences of each street dish. I have to say the mains do not seem to live up to the small dishes with the Burrito, the flagship dish of any Mexican restaurant, dry and clearly not prepared fresh and from scratch Also the vegetarian options seem to be basically nil. Only a salad there and a soup there...so don't go there with a veggie! Otherwise it remains my favourite Mexican restaurant franchise and is a nice, unpretentious and cheery place to eat in Canary Wharf.

IcrvHTIAC5l5v-z3qZhkKQ.text: It was so nice to get guacamole so similar to what we're used to eating. The pork tacos also delivered. They have a pretty big menu, so I'm sure there are lots of hits and lots of misses. We look forward to going back to find our favourites. We are so happy to have found a great Mexican place.

x5945B6RTT-5eMiHlySupQ.text: Well generally I can't get enough of Wahaca, and I don't know whether it was because it was a Sunday but the service was not great. My partners coke was served in a dirty glass that smelled pretty bad so he drank out of the bottle. The plates for sharing which were already on the table were also dirty, which left us dreading the food! However when it came it was as tasty as ever. But again it was hard to get the attention of the reluctant bored waiters to get the bill and get out of there!! Disappointed.

E5eds1RPYY8G7y4nbl4UAQ.text: The Mexican Wagamama. I have no idea how authentic the food is, but it is very tasty. The Canary Wharf venue is much more spacious than other branches with a lot of light. Service is very friendly - but bring your buddies and colleagues, and not your business partners. No reservations. At 12pm you can even get a table for a group, at 12.30pm it is packed.

XuV-UYLIwUpMwzVooS57xA.text: Came to London, went out with friends and ended up having Mexican food for dinner. As a part time Californian and a frequent visitor to Texas I am fussy about my Mexican food but this place was incredible. The quesadillas and soft tacos were smaller but filled with taste. The Tortilla soup was amazing with big pieces  of avocado, but the high point of the evening may have been the chisels with a cup of melted chocolate for dipping! a real must do if you're in Limehouse or Canary Wharf.

lVTTnF7JTFBR-uyz6qAytw.text: I am fan of Wahaca! The service, price, food and overall dining experience was great. I ordered British Steak the Mexican way (medium rare) and it was delicious. If you are looking for a place to go to with colleagues that is convenient, trendy and causal I highly recommend coming here. Also, you can't beat the location of this place as it's centrally located near all the major offices and rail station.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. British Steak the Mexican way (medium rare)! Delicious.

O1rgLvpe4gRZoHp1duxfSA.text: It's one of the worse Wahacas i've ever been to only because of the service. Our server didnt start to be particular friendly and hard to wave down, but by the time we finished dinner and were sitting around chatting, a server came by tossed some churros in our way, and continued walking. We were trying to wave him down but he didnt even bother with us and no one was in sight. We thought maybe it's on the house and ate it. 10 minutes later, our server came by and asked us if we ordered the churros and we said no but we couldnt find anyone so we thought it was on the house (some places actually have services and do that) and she began to LECTURE us in a very rude tone about how we shouldn't eat food that we didnt order,and then proceeded to put it on our bill, causing the another set of churros to come by and dropped off our table. We waved someone down to ask them what's going on, and then the server came again and lectured us AGAIN about how we ate the first churros (that we ended up paying for), while taking the new set away (despite it was actually made for us this time). Wahaca really needs to clean up their staff. Her name is Alice, btw, and her english was not very good.

DaPJyx1F28Am9sG4GUIahw.text: Having ordered my 'first time burrito' I spent the rest of the meal glancing at my friend's chicken and fish dishes with a hint of jealousy..Don't get me wrong - the burrito was nicely made, huge and with all the right flavours but it looked a bit boring whilst the chicken and fish could make your mouth water just by looking at the way it was served.Tacos had quite a plain taste as for my taste buds. Overall - lovely lunch and I'm coming back for the chicken ;)

8wRaqRJMDxJtXSh7olXMgw.text: It's a 4 star if you're not Mexican and 2 if you are so we'll meet in the middle. They do their best with the ingredients they can access so  on that. My biggest complain was using English instead of  Mexican cheese on some of the dishes. Either way it's a good attempt. :)

gezQED2VT0qvY5Q_8f8Q1A.text: Wahaca is a nice joint with a wonkily-spelled name.  Their food, in the main, is fresh, tasty, and well-presented.  -kinda like Baja Fresh, really.  The prices, however, aren't Baja Fresh, but rather you're-in-London-looking-for-a-four-leaf-clover-type-of-food-from-home-so-we'll-charge-you-big-bucks kind of money.  I'm from California; this is how I feel.  Like the high prices, breaded fish tacos (upwards of 9 quid), too, are a bit off-putting.  If I want bread on my fish, then I'll go to Toff's of Muswell Hill for cod and chips.Fortunately, they have Negra Modelo behind the bar, so that you may numb out a bit before the bill comes.Oh, and I do think that people living in LDN could be trained to pronounce the name "Oaxaca".  I really do.  (-maybe not "paella" though.)

nbdSSqMLELq68EIbeeJEEA.text: Wahaca is Wahaca wherever you go in London, so take it or leave it. Normally heaving at lunchtime with all the other workers of Canary Wharf, since it's one of the few fast options around. There's also a takeaway service inside and a food truck just outside, in Canada Square, where you can also pick up burritos and the like.

goZbyWHvrG2a2igsdcJMQQ.text: I am now a fan of this restaurant.  I came here with a group of friends for lunch and ordered a couple of dishes.  Even though the restaurant was pretty busy, I didn't feel like it was a long delay until I got my food.I had the pork pibil and the chorizo & potato - both starter sizes and probably designed for sharing, but I just ate all of it by myself!  The pork really hit the spot and the chorizo and potato was very tasty.  I washed it all down with an apple and rhubarb juice.I would be happy to come back here again, for lunch or dinner.  It looks ideal as a place to head to after work for some drinks and snacks.

v_5mxSs-wrbXn0rbk_YWww.text: When did Mexican start becoming so popular in London? This place was absolutely packed to the brim with gents and ladies in business suites. Unfortunately this hurt our experience here a bit, though.Due to rush hour, the waiter stopped by about 3 times saying he will attend to us. The second time he actually started taking our order and then bolted off half way through my order because he forgot to attend to another table first! Mate! Additionally, half way through my meal I realized my british steak burrito was cooked blue! The cow of which this fine piece of meat came from was pretty much still alive. Absolutely disgusting. I complained showing the manager it was barely simmered and he agreed and immediately took it off the bill, so props for customer service in that regard but I was still dissapointed I couldn't finish my burrito. Living in California, I have to say Wahaca is not at all authentic but I don't care because the rest of our food was delicious and it really does seem like a great place to come. Unlucky about our rude-ish waiter and poorly cooked steak but I'm willing to give Wahaca a second chance given the rest of the food and every other part of the experience was pretty good.

UenkLGM-qW7VhH0JaGI6lA.text: Delicious Mexican style food, good tacos and better shrimp cocktails. Very good option for thsi type of food lovers.

K3t09StD1Xx6kMWZw--BXg.text: I love a Wahaca.Canary Wharf Wahaca was my first experience of this Mexican inspired chain. Some say it's not authentic, I say I don't care, it tastes good. I like a little bit of this and a little bit of that and the 'street food' idea is right up my street. It's a colorful and vibrant restaurant without being overbearing. It's reasonably priced, your food comes out hot and quick and it is just lush, especially in comparison to some of the other restaurants in the area.

MWClnzhJ-11w3tJr7SkZiw.text: Excellent food, good service. It gets a five because I would have never guessed you could find a great Mexican place in London.The food had more of a Baja flair than traditional Mexican. We had the sampler and everything was great. Good sangrita as well. The only thing missing was a tamale.

HaSi397YbDs3iAzQRbYY1A.text: Wahaca normally provides very good service, and I love the attention to detail with which they've put the whole experience together. So was disappointed that waiter had a casual arrogance. I had to ask for a glass of water three times and the bill took way too long. Food was divine as always, the plaintain wrap being a special highlight.

MMtOledpVdUKFiG1BB8fPQ.text: I drank here a couple of weekends ago during the Canary Wharf Jazz festival.I'd eaten and drank at the Wahaca on Southbank and that experience was very poor (which I reviewed here) but I thought I give Wahaca (at least the drinks part) a second go as I was convinced that the first time I went the barman was just useless rather than the drink recipe being bad.So I ordered the same mojito DF drink that I ordered last year and low and behold the drink was excellently made. I won't be going back to the Southbank one anytime soon but I may just try to eat at another Wahaca in the near future.The view of Canada square is really great and you can open the windows fully which was great as we went on a hot summers day.There's always events happening in Canada Square so if you are there and fancy a break whilst maintaining a good view of what's going on then this is the bar that you should go to.

3xIxE0s9p4sVRfia4S9c5w.text: Gorgeously delicious Mexican food, reasonable prices, and friendly staff. You can't ask for much more.

EPTa5hp0KvoPvA5P7py3Xg.text: Super impressed with this place.  I wasn't expecting Cali style Mexican, but this place came dam close, and actually blew me away for Mexican food in the UK!  It's amost as good as my mum's home made stuff.  haha.The tacos were small, smaller than Mexico, but that's ok, because they were loaded with flavour.  Everything here was good, especially the mexican style of serving the beer. Margharitas were spot on, and service was incredible.

WpV4oQQa-f78EmUzQNGaDg.text: Always a pleasure to eat here. The street food style allows me to taste multiple dishes for a decent fare. Book in advance as evenings can be quite a wait. Their bar on the top floor is also decent where yummy nachos and dips go well with the booze.

NsCM7HD9bhmfPVpLsg1qUg.text: Excellent Mexican food in a very festive environment. The staff was quite friendly. The portions are quite small so you will need to order several of them. I tried three of the taco selections and all were amazing. Very creatively done with nice flavors and tastes.

BW7iRuatyzWP_ltPRjytzg.text: I must say that I rediscovered Mexican food here...When I was in the US, I didn't like Mexican restaurant because everything was too spicy or too heavy for me...then my former colleagues convinced me to go for lunch at Wahaca and I discovered a whole new world.The food is really good and not as heavy as the original mexican stuff, in particular the tapas style dishes to share: my favourites are the chicken taquitos, a cruncy roll filled with chicken and loaded with salad, cheese and tomato. The black been quesadillas are also very good, as well as the tacos. For lunch I have ordered sometimes the salads and wasn't disappointed at all,also because it comes in  crispy bread bowl.My friends used to have burritos and they were always very satisfied with the food. I like the atmosphere here, so colourful and bright. As the food comes when it is ready, there are no long waiting periods and the service is very fast. On top there is a nice terrace bar where to have a good Mojitos (but you can drink it also at the restaurant downstairs).I have been also to the Soho branch on a couple of Sunday nights and it was good too.

7FmxCMVyt1WJc81WPEl4YQ.text: Chains and branches, you sometimes get a bit wary and weary of them. However, not all are bad and some are worth the trip. I've been to Wahaca a few times now and I do enjoy the food here. When I don't really have a preference on what to order, I will usually go for the Market selection which comprises of a number of different items on the menu.  3 pork pibil tacos1 large broad bean quesadilla3 chicken tinga tacos2 black bean tostadas2 new potato taquitoswith green rice and black beansYou probably can't go too wrong with the above selections. Everything is cooked well, flavoursome and will satisfy the tummy. My favourite are the taquitos, anything deep fried usually are. Sometimes when you want to eat somewhere that doesn't burn a hole in the wallet and still taste of something, Wahaca is one of this options that I will consider.  Oh, and my favourite drink is the horchata which is almond and rice milk. A nice chill drink without being overly sweet.

cfZBGaOk8Hh_xifk-hicNg.text: Pretty good Mexican food.  I ordered the chicken mole enchiladas.  The mole sauce was good, but the corn tortillas seemed a bit greasy and there just wasn't much filling inside of the tortilla.My mom ordered the fish tacos and really enjoyed.We both had the Hibiscus punch which was pretty good.  They added cranberry juice to it, which I am not used to, so it was a bit off to me because of the added bitterness.A tad pricey for Mexican food.Overall a good experience.

RPAIQbm1mRbLoHr9ODEoFQ.text: There are two types of Mexican places in Canary Wharf and Wahaca is the more expensive as well as formal option. Whilst I would say the food itself is pretty average, I like that the staff are accommodating and it's a great place to host drinks looking over the green near One Canada Square. I recommend going in a group and sharing some small bites as well as ordering your own main. I usually go for the fish main which comes with rice and is zingy as well as being lighter than the larger taco bowl/burrito options. I've come here 5/6 times on different occasions and think it's usually a good choice for team lunch given everyone can order a main and just share some nachos and guac at the start.Drinks are reasonably priced and they have an unusual selection of tequilas etc. Food comes out as it's ready but it's a nice place for a date if you get a nice window seat rather than being sat by a big table.

N20t0fdSeAXNY0VD207Jlg.text: I should have known since they didn't spell it Oaxaca that I was in for an inauthentic experience. While traveling for business I stopped in for dinner on my way back to my hotel. The service was terrible and the food was worse. I got a salad and the chicken reminded me of what canned cat food smells like... the dressing was flavorless and just yuck. After the food was brought out we didn't see the server again until he dropped off the check. Didn't ask how it was, didn't check in on us, nothing. Then we played a 20-25 min game of cat and mouse. We FINALLY got him to come over and he was like "oh, I thought you were going to pay on the app." The Wi-Fi didn't work in there, and I had no cell service.... Not sure how I would have accomplished paying on the app but, mmmkay....Go anywhere else.... even a cart for street meat... ick.

LG2QyjeW67GSkTTyO-2ikQ.text: To be honest, it's okay. The place looks and sounds fancy and the prices match, but in the end, the food is just... okay? I don't need my tacos in little holders, and they've definitely mellowed out the flavours. If you want to advertise yourself as artisanal  Mexican, then maybe showcase the real flavours?In the end, its a decent meal, but it leaves me wanting more.

OwWX8TkZFJszCBUTNaE7ZQ.text: Didn't expect much from this Mexican place since I'm from Texas (definitely know authentic Mexican very well). The place is average and some of the food isn't really authentic (fried chicken in a taco, or the bigger sin...flour tortillas?!)I had a steak and it was okay. The meat was a bit chewy and you could tell it wasn't the best quality (but what do you expect from a steak that costs 14£. The good stuff here is the tacos. That's probably what is most tasty on their menu. I wouldn't get the horchata since it tasted really off and watered down (might be because they don't use cow milk, it taste more like almond which made the consistency a bit weird for me).The inside is beautifully decorated and its in a prime location in Canary Wharf. I wasn't expecting much and got exactly what I expected from a Mexican place in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

bT9vlztXwkM9MfMgsTX_gQ.text: We visited here on Friday night - it was a pre-concert meal and we decided to avoid the crowds at the O2 and head to Canary Wharf instead! I started with an Hibiscus - I'm not a huge fan of tequila but when paired with cranberry juice it goes down a treat! Just yummy. Wahaca's is always a good, go-to staple when you need fast and reliable food! I ordered the grilled British steak tacos, the Smoky chipotle chicken quesadillas and Frijoles. The food literally came within minutes and I mean minutes! The steak was hot, cooked well - a little over done for my liking but for tacos it worked well! The quesadillas were a little bland but I ate them all the same. The stand outs for me were the beans and Chris' sweet potatoes chips - they were delicious! soft but crispy and seasoned well.Sure wahaca's isn't the best Mexican food you'll find in London but it's easy, reasonable priced - £44 for 2 with 4 drinks, and the staff are friendly and helpful. We actually payed using flypay which made it even quicker to get in and out and off to the concert.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Steak tacos
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Chicken quesadillas
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Beans

x9jJljMQOc76SDQGbn5sxA.text: Love a good Taco, love some mexi. Here's a decent option for you!Love the food and setting. Price is reasonable (to canary wharf standard), and food is nice.Had a fish Taco and it tasted awesome!Only complaint is that it was too small. Think I can eat 3 of them to be full! No I don't eat a lot.

L4-H5BDC9KTLuxwL5Go_2Q.text: The Grilled MSC cod with green olive & herb salsa is pretty good surprisingly. The cod is fresh and nicely made. The rice and salad are ok though. But I give the cod 4 stars. The service is good and the waiter is good at handling a big group.

plVce8XxCiqscO8uqpqdtA.text: It's a no-surprise all-round 3 stars isn't it. It's your standard chain - nothing is ever gonna be awful, nothing is ever gonna be outstanding, but you always know what you're gonna get. Can't say better than that!!!Stand out dish was the crab and avocado tostada. That was deee-lish. Stand out bad dish was the chicken quesadilla - dry and very tasteless. No. Staff were lovely though, and I like the style of the menu where you can keep it there and just keep ordering as you eat. Grand!

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Crab and avocado tostado
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Yum cornnn
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Tequila water..

Dwvx6ldpFC2HH8Wg0LVSiQ.text: In the Canary Wharf/Docklands area there isn't a whole lot of choice for food outside your typical chain options. We ended up here for some food kind of by default - it seemed like the best option from the few choices we had. Wahaca reminds me a lot of Topolabomba in Glasgow (Wahaca came first, just to make that clear). It's casual, open-area dining with table service and this location in particular was rammed with business folk who'd just knocked off work (or were still working on their laptops at their tables). The menu is your placemat and there's a pretty massive range so you should be able to find something that you like. We got guacamole and frijoles to share between the table - both of these were super tasty but as my workmate mentioned, the guac didn't look super fresh and had turned a little grey in colour. I ordered: chicken taquitos, salmon sashimi tostadas and crab & avocado toastadas. This was the perfect amount of food for a late night dinner and with most things coming in at around £5, pretty damn good value too (esp for London). I can't decide which I liked the most as they were all pretty damn delicious - I would say the chicken taquito needed some seasoning as it was perhaps a tad bland but otherwise I really liked the food. I also tried a passion fruit margarita which was way too sweet but once I watered it down it was fine. We had churros to finish - these are a small portion of 3 churros and the sauce is super rich. I could have done without these as then I'd eaten way too much food. My workmate paid for the meal on the app which is a kind of cool idea - although, you need to know your table number and we couldn't find this anywhere so had to ask a waitress. Service was excellent and friendly and all up, I was pretty impressed with this place for a late-night dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Guacamole
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Frijoles
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Salmon sashimi tostada & chicken taquito

J77MAaqmTcLX4IK7JEt2iQ.text: Love this place for quick (most of the times) service, high quality food and good tequila and mezcal. I usually go for the steak burrito, and can't find any fault with it - the steak is juicy and tender, and there is a lot of it. Burritos in other places are sometimes 95% rice but here there is a lot of other good stuff thrown in in good proportions - nice cabbage slaw, good rice, and nice cheese. Also comes with a few tortilla chips and salsa - nice extra! This all for under £7 is an excellent deal for a dine in lunch or dinner. Also try sweet potato fries - to die for - and frijoles with chorizo (can be ordered with tortilla chips as a starter but if you order a burrito you get some chips anyway so can just order frijoles as a side because it's cheaper that way).

zark0JBHZqao5KLW6DLxsw.text: Sorry but the food was terrible. Guacamole was watered down and seemed old. Burrito was boring- just meat, rice and sauce. No sour cream, no lettuce, no pico de gallo- nothing good! Won't go back.

r_-MlyUh716KAK13hIacIw.text: Not exactly the kind of Mexican I'm used to, but the introduction menu to split between two was good and well priced. There was a lot of different food, but it all came at the same time. Because of this, you felt a little rushed to eat. The service was good though.

NIPhVT2qlcYrUcZ5l6Bhcg.text: Having lived in Southern California for many years, I know what Mexican food is. I know they are a 'boutique' Mexican restaurant,  but they missed it.  The chips are commercial,  made in a factory and not meant to be fresh. If you want  salsa with your chips, it costs more,  same if you wish to add guacamole,  that is to say you have to order that order, meaning one order chips and salsa and a second order of chips and guacamole. The guacamole was good. The Black Bean and cheese quesadilla was bland, dry and comes without any crema or salsa. I did not finish. My server never came back around so I could not get some mild chilli sauce.  I guess I'll wait until I go to the states to get Mexican food.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Guacamole & chips and a classic margarita!

_6DCP4WNkoORZiyQ0m78lw.text: Another great dinner at Wahaca. This is one of my favorite places to get a fast, inexpensive lunch or dinner. The food is always tasty and fast. Perfect for a fun lunch with friends or family.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Guacamole and chips & salsa :)

sTTpIosiN3MjMar7pEucow.text: Really nice food with a decent price

LYJiE0eDl-XPXELlh9TBgg.text: I really find this restaurant as a good alternative to the most places at Canary Wharf. Stuff is really nice and friendly. Its a bit crowded during the lunch time but you also can have take away.

-LPuGRRwIld4k9gTTAbnGg.text: Wahaca is right in be middle of Canary Wharf's Canada Square - in a great location - and perfect for meeting up with friends and colleagues for lunch or after work.It's a big space so I've never had to wait in a queue for seats during lunch or dinner, but there's always lots of people so it's buzzing so it's got a good vibe.In terms of the food itself, proper Mexican food in London simply doesn't exist so my standards are quite low - I'm not saying Wahaca's food is amazing but it's not bad either.  What I do like is it's tapas-style so small bites for many of the dishes so you get a variety...and they're priced fairly.  And most importantly, the food comes out fast!Service is good, fast, and friendly - look forward to future lunch/dinners here.FYI in the summers they've got a food truck outside where you can get tacos and sit on the grass at Canada Square - perfect way to enjoy the summer evenings after work.

2ei6IBOsN2Hz1SEn3BCNRQ.text: I think that Linzi wrote a great review of this place, way back when - wow - nearly 6 years ago now.Unlike Linzi at that point, I have spent quite a bit of time facedown in a lot of Californian Mexican-type grub. So, I could write this review from the point of "disappointment", but my expectations have been most definitely adjusted to fit what a London "Mexican" eatery will give me and what it will not.To be brief, I was not expecting outstanding service when I came here. And guess what? I didn't get outstanding service.I was not expecting to be bowled over by the greatest revolution in Mexican food since a man rode a little donkey across the border into California. And, you guessed it, the food was purely average representations of many dishes that we all know and (sometimes) love.The decor? The ambience? Ultra corporate. Ultra chain. No atmosphere. Apart from the clatter of dishes.So then. Just as I had thought. I was not expecting to be wowed and my expectations were met.

XvUkV_f9IqznH2JuRnCXRw.text: We went to meet friends for lunch and I suggested Wahaca, based on two fantastic experiences in the past and Wahaca lived up to its expectations, again!There was me (of course) and three vegetarians. It was a busy afternoon and we were told we'd be seated in a few minutes whilst we waited in the bar. The buzzer buzzed soon and we were on our way.We mostly ordered vegetarian options like plantain tacos, rice+beans, guac+nachos etc. I went for a chicken burrito and chicken quesadilla, in addition. We also had an almond/cinnamon/rice milk drink called horchata.The service was exceptional and so was the speed of service.Five stars again, cos simply they deserve it!As with any other place, I sincerely hope they continue to maintain their excellent standards.

EbTJx3GZKd0UGBZxWjaHtQ.text: Wahaca is one of the better places to grab Mexican food in London. My dining experiences at the Canary Wharf location have always been great. Service is fast and efficient, and the food is good. I like having the choice between getting 3-4 small plates or one entree.I highly recommend the plantain tacos - they're pretty darn tasty. I'm always down for a black bean and cheese quesadilla, and the steak tacos aren't half bad either. This particular Wahaca location has a great outdoor bar looking over a park. In the summers you can sit out here and watch Wimbledon matches on 2 huge outdoor television while sipping on margaritas.
